journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Effect of bond on compressive behaviour of flax fibre reinforced polymer tube–confined coir fibre reinforced concrete

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, The University of Auckland, Auckland Mail Centre, Auckland, New Zealand
2École Nationale des Travaux Publics de l'État, Rue Maurice Audin, Vaulx-en-Velin Cedex, France

author-notes.corresp: Libo Yan, Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, The University of Auckland, Level 11, Engineering Building, 20 Symonds Street, Auckland 1001, New Zealand. Email: lyan118@aucklanduni.ac.nz

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This study investigated the effect of flax fibre reinforced polymer and concrete bond on the compressive behaviour of flax fibre reinforced polymer–confined plain concrete and coir fibre reinforced concrete. Three types of bond were considered, i.e. concrete confined by (1) flax fibre reinforced polymer tube, (2) flax fibre reinforced polymer tube with internal flax fibre reinforced polymer rings and (3) flax fibre reinforced polymer wrapping. They were termed as naturally, mechanically and adhesively bonded, respectively. A total of 18 flax fibre reinforced polymer–confined plain concrete and coir fibre reinforced concrete cylinders were tested under axial compression. The test results indicated that all the three flax fibre reinforced polymer confinements increased the ultimate compressive strength and ductility of the concrete significantly compared to the unconfined concrete. It was found that the type of flax fibre reinforced polymer and concrete bond has a significant effect on the ultimate strength and axial strain of the confined cylinders. The composite cylinder with naturally bonded offered the largest ultimate strength and axial strain. In all cases of flax fibre reinforced polymer–confined coir fibre reinforced concrete, the coir fibre inclusion reduced the numbers and widths of the cracks in the concrete. Additionally, existing confinement stress and strain models were used to predict the experimental results of the confined plain concrete and coir fibre reinforced concrete cylinders.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: It is well known that fibre reinforced polymer (FRP) material as external confinement of concrete enhances concrete axial compressive strength and ductility significantly.1 The confinement mechanism can be achieved by including FRP-wrapping of existing concrete (i.e. FRP-wrapped concrete) columns or encasement of concrete in a hollow FRP tube (i.e. CFFT) for new construction.

An extensive research has been conducted on the confinement performance of FRP-wrapped concrete2,3 and CFFT.4,5 Actually, there is a distinctive difference between the two types of FRP-confined concrete, i.e. the concrete in FRP-wrapped concrete is adhesively bonded to the FRP, but this bonding does not exist in CFFT. FRP and concrete interfacial bond condition may play an important role in the performance of FRP-confined concrete because the stresses transfer from concrete to FRP is through the interface.

However, the effect of bond condition on the performance of FRP-confined concrete has been ignored in most of the studies in the last decade. Only a few studies are available on this subject from the literature. An earlier study by Mirmiran et al.6 investigated the effect of bond condition on FRP-wrapped concrete and CFFT. The test results showed insignificant differences in the column capacity due to the bond effect, i.e. the ultimate axial compressive strength and strain of three-layer FRP-wrapped concrete and CFFT are 65.5 MPa and 2.9% and are 62.8 MPa and 2.7%, respectively. The GFRP material considered in the study has a tensile modulus of 55.85 GPa and a tensile strength of 1800 MPa.

Fam and Rizkalla7 evaluated the effect of GFRP tube/concrete interface condition on the confinement performance. The condition considered included a smooth (natural) and roughened interface. To provide a roughened interface, a thin layer of epoxy was applied to the inner tube surface and later silica sand was sprayed on the top of the tacky epoxy. The results indicated that the interface condition had an insignificant effect on the ultimate compressive strength and axial strain of the specimens. Shahawy et al.8 stated that compared with that of CFFT, the adhesive bond between concrete and the FRP wrap does not appear to affect the confinement behaviour significantly. Therefore, the same confinement model can be applied to CFFT and FRP-wrapped concrete cylinders. But the experiments carried out by Wakodikar9 and Rajanikanth10 on GFRP-confined concrete, on the other hand, showed a different result. In their studies, two types of FRP jacketing were considered, i.e. pre-jacketing and post-jacketing. The GFRP material used by Wakodikar9 and Rajanikanth10 has the tensile strength ranging from 102 to 175.5 MPa and the tensile modulus ranging from 2.67 to 4.66 GPa. The pre-jacketing method is the same as that of CFFT, i.e. the tube is pre-fabricated and fresh concrete was poured into the tube as naturally bonded interface between FRP and concrete. For post-jacketing, concrete cylinders were cast and cured, and then a thin layer of epoxy was applied to the surface of the concrete before the installation of the FRP jackets as adhesively bonded case. The test results by Wakodikar9 showed that the post-jacketed cylinder (FRP-wrapped concrete) gained a higher strength, i.e. 72% compared to the unconfined concrete. But in the case of pre-jacketed technique (CFFT), the increase in strength is much less, i.e. 31%, and it happened because of the separation between FRP and concrete surface as a result of the absence of bond, as explained by Wakodikar.

Rajanikanth10 found that the pre-jacketed cylinders with 1-layer and 2-layer GFRP increased the strength by 10% and 19%, respectively, while the post-jacketed cylinders with 1-layer and 2-layer GFRP increased in strength by 19% and 35%, respectively, compared to the unconfined concrete. Rajanikanth explained the smaller gain in strength of the pre-jacketed cylinder due to the very weak bond between the concrete and the GFRP tube. The results provided by Wakodikar and Rajanikanth indicated that FRP-wrapped concrete (adhesively bonded) exhibits higher enhancement in load-carrying capacity, compared to the FRP tube–confined concrete (naturally bonded).

Deb and Bhattacharyya11 used a finite-element method to study the type of bond condition effect on the ultimate strength of GFRP-confined concrete, where the FRP materials have the same mechanical properties as considered by Wakodikar9 and Rajanikanth.10 The numerical study showed that the GFRP and concrete bond had a significant effect on the effectiveness of the confinement mechanism and thus influenced the failure load and ultimate strain of FRP-confined concrete columns. The FRP-wrapped concrete had a much larger failure load compared to the CFFT as a result of good FRP and concrete bond.

Saafi et al.12 also stated that the bond between FRP and concrete influences the load-carrying capacity of a FRP confined concrete column. The stress and strain equations developed for FRP-wrapped concrete are not applicable to FRP tubes. These equations usually underestimate the axial strain and overestimate the axial compressive strength for FRP tube–confined concrete. In summary, the study by Mirmiran et al.6 stated that FRP and concrete bond condition has no significant differences on ultimate strength and strain but Wakodikar,9 Rajanikanth10 and Deb and Bhattacharyya11 concluded that the bond influenced the ultimate strength of FRP-confined concrete remarkably, especially for the considered GFRP materials with the low tensile properties. In addition, Shahawy et al.8 stated a same confinement stress–strain model can be applied to CFFT and FRP-wrapped concrete cylinders but Saafi et al.12 reported that the stress and strain equations developed for FRP-wrapped concrete are not applicable to FRP tubes. Therefore, the results of type of bond effect on FRP-confined concrete are conflicting. Thus, further research on this subject is needed to clarify the type of bond effect on FRP-confined concrete, especially for a new kind of FRP confined concrete considered in this study, i.e. natural flax FRP (FFRP)–confined concrete.

Most recently, Yan and Chouw13 proposed a natural FRP tube confined concrete, i.e. FFRP tube–confined plain concrete (PC) and coir fibre reinforced concrete (CFRC). The FFRP tube confinement increased the axial compressive strength and structural ductility of the concrete remarkably. From the perspective of environmentally friendly, the use of natural fibres can promote more sustainable construction materials because natural fibres are cost-effective with low density, and they are also biodegradable and readily available. Flax fabric in the form of post-jacket technique may also be considered as a retrofit measure of existing concrete structures.

Regarding the natural flax FRP-confined concrete (PC and CFRC), there is an issue which need to be addressed: how does the type of FFRP and concrete bond conditions affect the confinement behaviour of the concrete? In other words, can a confinement stress or strain model be equally applied to flax FRP tube–confined concrete and flax FRP-wrapped concrete? Note that in the former case, a natural bond of a small magnitude is developed as fresh concrete is poured into the FFRP tube, whereas in the latter case, FFRP jacket is bonded to the concrete by an adhesive. Therefore, the purpose of this study is to investigate the effect of type of bond on the compressive behaviour of FFRP-confined PC and CFRC. Three different types of FFRP and concrete bond were considered, i.e. PC and CFRC-confined by (1) FFRP tube as naturally bonded, (2) FFRP wrapping as adhesively bonded and (3) FFRP tube with embedded internal rings as mechanically bonded. In addition, whether the stress and strain models can be equally applied for both FFRP tube and FFRP-wrapped concrete will be evaluated.

sec.title: Material and fabrication process
sec.p:
Commercial bidirectional woven flax fabric (550 g/m2) was used in this study. The fabric has a plain woven structure with count of 7.4 threads/cm in warp and in the weft directions.14 The structure of the flax fabric was given in a previous study.15 The epoxy used was the SP High Modulus Ampreg 22 resin and hardener. The properties of flax fibre and epoxy are displayed in Table 1. FFRP tubes were fabricated using the hand lay-up process by wrapping resin-impregnated fabrics around an aluminium mould with a diameter of 100 mm and a length of 300 mm. For each tube, the arrangement of flax fabric considered was 4-layer. The aluminium mould was first cut longitudinally and then taped tightly to make a formwork for FRP wrapping, while allowing easy removal of the tube after the curing of FFRP. Then the aluminium mould was covered with a layer of infusion sheet, so that the cured FFRP tubes can be easily detached. The fabric sheets were cut to appropriate length for each layer of wraps, with a minimum of 157 mm of overlap (half perimeter of the concrete core). More details about the fabrication were given in the study.13 Fabric fibre orientation was at 90° from the axial direction of the tube. The mechanical properties of flax FRP composites are listed in Table 2. Typical tensile stress–strain curve of flax FRP composite obtained from a flat coupon test is displayed in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Typical tensile stress-strain curve of flax fibre reinforced polymer (FRP) composite in flat coupon test. Table 1.
Mechanical properties of fibre and epoxy
Material Diameter (mm) Density (g/cm3) Elastic modulus (GPa) Tensile strength (MPa) Elongation (%)
Flax fibre 0.708 1.43 16.4 153.8 3.2
Epoxy – 1.09 3.6 87.8 4.5
Table 2.
Mechanical properties of flax FRP composites
Composite thickness (mm) Tensile strength (MPa) Tensile modulus (GPa) Tensile strain (%) Flexural strength (MPa) Flexural Modulus (GPa) Fibre volume fraction (%) Density of FFRP (g/cm3)
6.50 134 9.5 4.3 144 8.7 55.1 1.27

To construct FFRP-confined concrete cylinder, one end of the FFRP tube was placed with wooden plate acting as the mould, and the concrete was poured. For FFRP tube with internal rings, after the fabrication of the tubes, three extra flax/epoxy rings were placed into the inner tubes using the hand lay-up process. The three internal rings were uniformly distributed along the longitudinal direction of the tube, as displayed in Figure 2. Each internal ring was made by two layers of flax FRP laminate with a width of 15 mm and an overlap of 157 mm. Figure 2.
Flax fibre reinforced polymer (FFRP) tube with three internal rings (a) and shape of concrete core in FFRP tube with rings (b).

For FFRP-wrapped concrete, PC and CFRC cylinders were cast and cured for 28 days. After drying out, the surface of the cylinder was polished and impregnated with a thin layer of epoxy using a brush. Then, resin-impregnated flax fabrics were placed on the concrete surface with the epoxy. The specimens were dried at room temperature for 24 h and placed into an oven and cured at 65°C for 7 h.

Table 3 gives the test matrix of the specimens. A total of 30 cylinders were constructed. The specimens include six unconfined PC, six unconfined CFRC, nine FFRP-confined PC and other nine FFRP-confined CFRC cylinders. For the unconfined PC and CFRC, three of these specimens were tested at 28-days and all the other specimens were tested at 240 days. The height of all the specimens is 200 mm and the diameter of concrete core is 100 mm. The specimens tested at 240 days are evenly divided into eight types: (1) unconfined PC, (2) unconfined CFRC, (3) FFRP tube-PC, (4) FFRP tube-CFRC, (5) FFRP-wrapped PC, (6) FFRP-wrapped-CFRC, (7) FFRP tube-ring-PC and (8) FFRP tube-ring-CFRC. The unconfined PC is designed with a 28-day compressive strength of 30 MPa. For PC specimens, the mix proportions used for cement: gravel: sand: water was respectively 1:3.82:2.27:0.55, followed by ACI 211. 1.16 For CFRC specimens, coir fibre was used during mixing with fibre content of 1% by mass of the cement. The average mechanical properties of coir fibres are listed in Table 4. Table 3.
Test matrix of the specimens
Specimen cases No. of specimens Coir fibre length (mm) Compressive strength test
PC 3 – 28-day
CFRC 3 50 28-day
PC 3 – 240-day
CFRC 3 50 240-day
4L-FFRP-T-PC 3 – 240-day
4L-FFRP-T-CFRC 3 50 240-day
4L-FFRP-TR-PC 3 – 240-day
4L-FFRP-TR-CFRC 3 50 240-day
4L-FFRP-W-PC 3 – 240-day
4L-FFRP-W-CFRC 3 50 240-day
4L: 4-layer fabric; CFRC: coir fibre reinforced concrete; FFRP: flax fibre reinforced polymer; FFRP-T: flax FRP tube; FFRP-TR: FFRP tube with three inner rings; FFRP-W: FFRP-wrapped.
Table 4.
Average mechanical properties of coir fibre
Properties Coir fibre
Diameter (mm) 0.25
Length (mm) 50
Density (g/cm3) 1.20
Tensile modulus (GPa) 2.74
Tensile stress at break (MPa) 226
Tensile strain at break (%) 17.8

Before testing, the ends of all the specimens were treated with high-quality mortar to ensure a uniform bearing surface. In the case of FFRP-confined specimens, the lower and upper edges of the FFRP jackets were removed using a blade to avoid a direct load bearing on the FFRP jacket during the axial compression test.

sec.title: Axial compression test
sec.p:
For each cylinder, two strain gauges were mounted at mid-height of a cylinder aligned along the hoop direction to measure hoop strain. Two linear variable displacement transducers (LVDTs) were placed 180° apart and spaced at the mid-height of the cylinder to measure axial strain, as shown in Figure 3. Compression test was conducted on an Avery-Denison machine under stress control with a constant rate of 0.20 MPa/s based on ASTM C39.17 Each sample was axially compressed up to failure. The readings of the strain gauges and LVDTs were taken using a data logging system. Figure 3.
Schematic view of axial compression test setup.

sec.title: Stress–strain behaviour
sec.p:
Axial compressive stress versus axial strain curves of the tested specimens is displayed in Figure 4. In general, the axial stress–strain response of FFRP tube-PC and tube-CFRC are similar to the FFRP-wrapped confined PC and FFRP-wrapped CFRC; all the cylinders exhibit an approximate bi-linear behaviour with a sustainable ascending branch at the second linear stage. However, the curves of FFRP tube-ring PC and CFRC are quite different. The curve starts with an ascending initial linear stage, and then followed by a nonlinear “plateau” without stress increase at the beginning of the second region; eventually the behaviour becomes approximately linear again at the latter third part of the curve. Figure 4.
Axial compressive stress–strain curves: (a) flax fibre reinforced polymer (FFRP)-confined plain concrete (PC) and (b) FFRP-confined coir fibre reinforced concrete (CFRC).

In all the cases of FFRP-confined PC or CFRC, the first purely linear response is similar to the corresponding unconfined PC or CFRC. When the applied stress exceeds the ultimate strength of unconfined PC or CFRC, in the case of FFRP tube and FFRP-wrapped concrete, the curve enters the second linear region where considerable micro-cracks are developed in concrete and the FFRP jacket starts to confine the concrete core. This second approximate linear region is mainly dominated by the structural behaviour of FFRP composites where the tube is fully activated to confine the core, leading to a considerable enhancement in the concrete compressive strength and ductility. In the case of FFRP tube-ring confined concrete, when the curve enters the second region, unlike that in FFRP tube–confined concrete, the activation of the confinement of the FFRP tube is restricted because the internal rings prevent the considerable lateral expansion of the concrete core. With an increase of axial stress, the FFRP rings with the concrete core carry the compressive load. When the applied load exceeds the bond stress between the FFRP tube and the rings, the internal rings debond from the FFRP tube (Figure 8). The confinement of the FFRP tube is then fully activated and leads to a linear response at the latter of the second region. When the axial stress increases, the hoop tensile stress in the FFRP jacket also increases. Once this hoop stress exceeds the ultimate tensile strength of FFRP jacket failure starts. Figure 8.
Failure modes of the concrete cores after removing the outer flax fibre reinforced polymer (FFRP).

The axial compressive stress versus hoop strain responses of the tested specimens are illustrated in Figure 5. The axial stress-hoop strain responses of FFRP tube-PC or CFRC and FFRP-wrapped-PC or CFRC also display an approximate bi-linear relationship. However, for FFRP tube-ring-CFRC, the second region of the response exhibits a nonlinear behaviour, which is similar to the second region of the axial stress vs. axial-strain curve for FFRP tube-ring-CFRC in Figure 4(b). Compared with the second linear response of FFRP tube-ring-PC in Figure 5(a), this nonlinearity of FFRP tube-ring-CFRC in Figure 5(b) may be interpreted by the presence of coir fibre which affects the stress distribution at the mid-length of the FFRP tube with internal rings. Figure 5.
Axial compressive stress-hoop strain curves: (a) flax fibre reinforced polymer (FFRP)-confined plain concrete (PC) and (b) FFRP-confined coir fibre reinforced concrete (CFRC).

sec.title: Confinement performance
sec.p:
Table 5 gives the results of specimens tested at 240-days. f'co represents the peak compressive strength of unconfined concrete and f'cc is the ultimate compressive strength of confined concrete. ɛco is the axial strain of unconfined concrete at peak strength, ɛcc is the ultimate axial strain of the confined concrete, f'cc/f'co is the confinement effectiveness. ɛcc/ɛco is the axial strain ratio which can be used to define the ductility of FRP confined concrete,6 fl is the lateral confining pressure between the FFRP tube and the concrete core. 4L: 4-layer fabric; CFRC: coir fibre reinforced concrete; FFRP: flax fibre reinforced polymer; PC: plain concrete; FFRP-T: flax FRP tube; FFRP-TR: FFRP tube with three inner rings; FFRP-W: FFRP-wrapped.
Note: The corresponding * values were used for f'cc/f'co and ɛcc/ɛco calculation.

Table 5 shows that the coir fibre inclusion reduced the compressive strength of the CFRC (30.1 MPa), compared to the unconfined PC (32.0 MPa) tested at 240 days. The data here is opposite to the test result tested at 28 days. The average compressive strength of PC and CFRC were 31.2 MPa and 32.8 MPa, respectively. Coir fibre inclusion led to a 2.2% increase in the strength at 28 days. The compressive strength of CFRC at 240 days reduced with the aging from 32.8 to 30.1 MPa (–8.2%). This fact indicates that coir fibres immersed in Portland cement may degrade due to the hydration of cement paste which creates an alkaline environment, thus weakening the strength of the structure. Natural fibres consist of lignin, hemicellulose and cellulose that react with the cement matrix, especially at the fibre and cement matrix interfaces, this leads to the degradation in the composite structure.18,19 A reduction in compressive strength of CFRC with aging has been observed in the study by Islam et al.20 To improve the durability of natural fibre-reinforced concrete, two methods could be considered as suggested by Pacheco-Torgal and Jalali21: (1) matrix modification using low alkaline concrete by adding pozzolanic by-products (e.g., silica fume or rice hush ash) to Portland cement and (2) coating of natural fibres to avoid water absorption and free alkalis with application of water-repellent agents or fibre impregnation using sodium silicate, sodium sulphite or magnesium sulphate. However, compared with PC, coir fibre significantly increased the axial strain at peak compressive strength independent of aging. This is believed attributed to the coir fibre bridging effect.

In general, the confinement provided by the three different FFRP systems enhanced the ultimate compressive strength and ultimate axial/hoop strains of both PC and CFRC. The confinement effectiveness of FFRP tube, FFRP tube-ring and FFRP-wrapped-PC and CFRC are 1.94, 1.69 and 1.65 and are 1.94, 1.73 and 1.62, respectively. The average axial strain ratios of PC confined by FFRP tube, FFRP wrapping and FFRP tube-ring are 10.95, 8.91 and 10.32, respectively, and are 4.01, 3.35 and 3.10, respectively, in the corresponding confined CFRC. This data indicates that all the three FFRP confinement increased the ductility of the concrete remarkably.

Figure 6 illustrates the type of FFRP and concrete bond effect on the confinement effectiveness of the specimens. With respect to the confined PC, FFRP tube-PC (naturally bonded) has the largest ultimate axial compressive strength and axial strain (Table 5). Compared with the ultimate stress (62.2 MPa) and ultimate axial strain (1.94%) of the naturally bonded composite, the strength and strain of the mechanically bonded composite reduced to 54 MPa (a reduction of 13.2%) and 1.69% (a reduction of 12.9%), respectively. The reduction in the strength is believed to be attributed to the existing of the internal rings, which leads to a nonuniform cross-sectional area of the concrete core. Thus, a higher stress concentration is generated at the cross-sectional area A2, as displayed in Figure 2. As the lateral confining pressure has a linear relationship with the actual tensile stress of the FFRP in its hoop direction, thus, the stress concentration at the concrete core leads to the reduction in confinement effect of FFRP tube. Figure 6.
Confinement effectiveness versus bond conditions.

Compared with the naturally bonded composite, both FFRP-wrapped-PC and FFRP-wrapped-CFRC (adhesively bonded composite) exhibited lower confinement effectiveness. The reduction in ultimate strength of FFRP-wrapped-PC and FFRP-wrapped-CFRC are 15.0% (from 58.2 MPa to 51.8 MPa) and 16.3% (from 58.2 MPa to 48.7 MPa), respectively. This observation contradicts the result reported by Wakodikar9 and Rajanikanth10 on GFRP-confined concrete, where the ultimate strength of GFRP-wrapped concrete is much larger than that of the GFRP tube-concrete, although the tensile properties of FFRP composites is close to that of GFRP considered in the studies.9,10

With regard to FFRP-confined CFRC, the strength gained are 6.4%, 4.6% and 7.9% lower than the corresponding FFRP tube, FFRP tube-ring and FFRP-wrapped-PC. In all the cases of FFRP-confined CFRC, the reduction in ultimate strength may be attributed to the degradation of coir fibre in the Portland cement since the 240-day compressive strength of unconfined PC (32.0 MPa) is larger than that of the unconfined CFRC (30.1 MPa).

sec.title: Failure mode
sec.p:
Figure 7 displays the failure modes of the specimens. For both PC and CFRC, the naturally bonded and mechanically bonded composites failed by the formation of a single straight crack throughout the longitudinal direction of the tubes, as fabric fibre orientation was at 90° from the axial direction of the tube. For both PC and CFRC, in the adhesively bonded composite the crack initiated at one end of the jacket and then propagated to the mid-length of the tube. The observation indicates that the type of FFRP and concrete bond also affects the failure mode of the FFRP jacket. The failure mode of FFRP-wrapped-concrete implies that there was a strong stress concentration at the end of the cylinder due to the combination of tensile and axial compressive stresses in the FFRP jacket under the compression. Figure 7.
Failure modes of the specimens.

Crack patterns of the concrete core were examined by removing the FFRP jackets, as illustrated in Figure 8. For the naturally bonded composite, the tubes were removed from the cores with ease. This implies that the tubes had no attachment to the cores, indicating a very weak FFRP/concrete interfacial bond. The PC core was crushed and spalled, but the CFRC core only had visible macro-cracks showing the advantageous of coir fibre inclusion. This observation demonstrates that the presence of coir fibre reduced the number and width of the cracks as a result of fibre bridging effect. In the case of mechanically bonded composites, the removal of the tube is relatively difficult compared to the naturally bonded case, showing a relatively strong bond at the FFRP and the concrete interface. Both PC and CFRC cores had visible cracks but still maintained as a whole. The FFRP rings debonded from the tube and integrated with the concrete to prevent the collapse of the core. In this case, the presence of their internal rings played a predominated role in controlling the propagation of the cracks. With respect to the adhesively bonded composites, it is difficult to remove the outer FFRP jacket from both PC and CFRC cores, indicating a very good bond between the FFRP and the core. It was observed that the PC core was separated to two halves but the CFRC core was intact after the removal of the jackets. Overall, the failure modes indicate that the type of bond affects the crack patterns of the concrete cores. For all the considered types of bond, the coir fibre inclusion reduced the number and width of the cracks of FFRP-confined concrete.

Although in this study push-out testing22 was not performed to measure the actual bond strength between FFRP and concrete for the three considered cases, however, according to the above discussion on the work required to remove these FFRP jackets from the concrete cores, it can be concluded that the naturally bonded composite has the smallest FFRP and concrete interfacial bond strength and the adhesively bonded one has the largest one. We recall that for both PC and CFRC cases, the naturally bonded composite had the largest compressive strength and the adhesively bonded one had the smallest compressive strength. We can state that there is a link between the FFRP and concrete bond strength and the ultimate compressive strength gain of the FFRP-confined concrete, i.e. in this study a weak FFRP and concrete interfacial bond strength leads to a larger ultimate compressive strength of the composite member. Indeed, the interfacial bond affects the state of stress in the FFRP jacket and may also affect the load-carrying capacity of the cylinder. It should be noted here that before testing the lower and upper edges of all the FFRP jackets were removed to avoid a direct load bearing of the FFRP jacket. This means that for FFRP tube–confined concrete (naturally bonded composite), the FFRP tube only subject to the tension in the hoop direction, while the adhesively bonded FFRP is subject to the hoop tension as well as axial compression due to the good interfacial bond. A combination of the stresses reduces the confinement level of the FFRP jacket and thus leads to a lower ultimate stress of FFRP wrapped concrete.

sec.title: Prediction of ultimate axial stress and strains
sec.p:
Previous study by the authors evaluated the effectiveness of the existing confinement models on the confinement performance of FFRP tube-PC and tube-CFRC cylinders.13 In the study, a total of 23 design-oriented and analysis-oriented stress–strain models have been considered. The evaluation focused on the prediction of the ultimate axial compressive strength and axial strain of the FFRP tube–confined concrete because they are the two most significant parameters for FRP-confined concrete design. The study showed that the design-oriented strength models by Wu et al.23 and Lam and Teng24 and an analysis-oriented strength model by Harries and Kharel25 predicted the ultimate strength of FFRP tube-PC and tube-CFRC accurately. None of the strain models considered matched the ultimate axial strains of FFRP tube-PC and tube-CFRC. Therefore, two strain equations were proposed and fitted the experimental results effectively. The stress models by Wu et al., Lam and Teng, Harries and Kharel and the strain models by Yan and Chouw13 are listed in Table 6. Table 6.
Some stress and strain models for FFRP tube confined concrete
Authors Stress or strain models
Wu et al.23 and Lam & Teng24
fcc'f'co=1+2(flf'co)
Harries and Kharel25
f'cc=f'co+4.629fl0.587
Yan and Chouw13 Model I*
ɛccɛco=0.46+6.21(f'ccf'co)0.7
Yan and Chouw13 Model II*
ɛccɛco=0.718+5.385(f'ccf'co)
FFRP: flax fibre reinforced polymer; CFRC: coir fibre reinforced concrete. *
ɛco of unconfined plain concrete is also considered for calculation of confined CFRC.

Table 7 makes a comparison between the predicted ultimate strength/strain and the experimental results. It indicates that the predicted ultimate stress based on the analysis-oriented strength model by Harries and Kharel25 matches the experimental ultimate stress very well, with the difference below 10%. The models developed by Wu et al. and Lam and Teng slightly overestimated the ultimate compressive strength of FFRP tube-CFRC, with the difference of 11.5%. For all the FFRP tube-ring-PC and tube-ring-CFRC and FFRP-wrapped PC and FFRP-wrapped CFRC, the strength models by Wu et al.23 and Lam and Teng24 overestimated their ultimate strengths significantly, with the differences between 23.5% and 33.3%. The predictions based on the model by Harries and Kharel25 still fitted the ultimate strengths of all FFRP-tube-ring and FFRP-wrapped PC and CFRC well, with the differences from 5.0% to 12.7%. Therefore, it can be concluded that the stress model proposed by Harries and Kharel is still acceptable to predict the ultimate strength for both FFRP tube and FFRP-wrapped PC and CFRC. Table 7.
Comparison of predicted ultimate axial stress and strain of FFRP tube-confined PC and CFRC
Specimens Experimental f'cc/ɛcc (MPa/%) References [23 and 24] Reference [25] Model I [13] Model II [13]
f'cc (MPa) % diff. f'cc (MPa) % diff. ɛcc (%) % diff. ɛcc (%) % diff.
FFRP-T-PC 62.2/2.41 66.8 7.4 56.8 −8.6 2.28 −5.4 2.46 2.1
FFRP-T-CFRC 58.2/2.49 64.9 11.5 54.9 −5.7 2.27 −8.8 2.45 −1.6
FFRP-TR-PC 54.1/1.96 66.8 23.5 56.8 5.0 2.28 16.3 2.46 25.5
FFRP-TR-CFRC 51.8/2.08 64.9 25.3 54.9 6.0 2.27 9.1 2.45 17.8
FFRP-W-PC 52.9/2.27 66.8 26.3 56.8 7.4 2.28 0.4 2.46 8.4
FFRP-W-CFRC 48.7/1.93 64.9 33.3 54.9 12.7 2.27 17.6 2.45 26.9
CFRC: coir fibre reinforced concrete; FFRP: flax fibre reinforced polymer; PC: plain concrete; FFRP-T: flax FRP tube; FFRP-TR: FFRP tube with three inner rings; FFRP-W: FFRP-wrapped.
Note: % diff. = 100 × [(prediction – test)/test].

The proposed two strain models predicted the ultimate axial strains of both FFRP tube-PC and tube-CFRC accurately, with the difference between –8.8% and 2.08%. However, both strain models I and II overestimated the ultimate axial strains of FFRP-tube and FFRP-wrapped PC and CFRC with the difference up to 26.9%. Therefore, an accurate strain model should be developed for FFRP-wrapped concrete when more FFRP-wrapped concrete specimens with different parameters be further considered, i.e. with different concrete compressive strength and numbers of FFRP laminates.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
This study focused on the effect of type of FFRP and concrete bond on the axial compressive behaviour of FFRP–confined plain concrete (PC) and coir fibre reinforced concrete (CFRC). Three types of bond condition were considered, i.e. concrete confined by (1) FFRP tube as naturally bonded, (2) FFRP tube with internal connector rings as mechanically bonded and (3) FFRP wrapping as adhesively bonded. In addition, confinement stress and strain models were used to predict the ultimate stress and strain for all the tested specimens, in order to determine if a confinement stress or strain model can be equally applied to flax FRP tube–confined concrete and flax FRP-wrapped concrete. The following conclusions can be drawn based on the study:
Coir fibre inclusion reduced the compressive strength of the concrete with aging due to the degradation of fibre in an alkaline environment in the Portland cement. However, the coir fibre on the enhancement of the axial strain at peak strength is noticeable.
For both PC and CFRC, the considered three types of FFRP confinement greatly enhance the strength and ductility of the unconfined concrete.
In the cases of both PC and CFRC, the type of bond has a significant effect on the failure modes and ultimate compressive strength of specimens. Naturally bonded composite has the largest ultimate compressive strength and axial strain and the adhesively bonded composite offers the smallest ultimate compressive strength.
The experimental results observed in this study indicated that a weak FFRP and concrete bond leads to a large ultimate stress gain of the composite, which contradicts the outcomes given in the studies,9,10 although the tensile properties of flax FRP composites are close to that of GFRP materials in their studies.
For all the types of bond conditions, coir fibre inclusion reduced the ultimate compressive strength of the confined CFRC compared to the corresponding FFRP-confined PC. However, coir fibre inclusion can control the failure mode of the concrete by reducing the number and width of the cracks as a result of fibre bridging effect.
Regarding both PC and CFRC, the axial stress–strain responses of naturally bonded and adhesively bonded composites exhibit distinct bi-linear relationship. However, in the case of mechanically bonded, the presence of internal rings affects the end phase development of the relationship.
The stress model by Harries and Kharel25 can be used to predict the ultimate compressive strength for all the FFRP tube, FFRP tube-ring and FFRP-wrapped confined PC and CFRC. The considered strain model predicted the ultimate axial strains of FFRP tube-PC and tube-CFRC accurately, but overestimated the axial strain for FFRP tube-ring and FFRP-wrapped confined PC and CFRC. An accurate strain model should be developed for FFRP tube-ring and FFRP-wrapped confined concrete.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
